While the ED, patient developed projectile feculent vomiting and was intubated for airway protection. He lives at . Per report, has had increased falls at assisted living, reportedly fell yesterday. This has been associated with a decreased mental status over the course of the day on , and he was also reported unable to stand. He was brought to the ED and was noted to be non verbal, though typically can speak per report. His initial ED evaluation was generally unremarkable. He was awake but minimally responsive to questions word answers). Initial vitals: temp 99.4, HR 102, BP 132/68, RR 16, and O2 99% RA. Labs notable for: no leukocytosis (WBC 5.1), Hgb 12.0 > 10.5, and lactate that downtrended (2.9 > 1.8 -> 1.3) with 2 or 3L IVF. Imaging notable for: CXR without significant change from prior study CT A/P with rectal wall thickening and hyperemia compatible with proctitis, fluid-filled non-dilated loops of small and large bowel likely representing viral gastroenteritis, and cholelithiasis without signs of cholecystitis. CT Spine with mild to moderate distention of thoracic esophagus with fluid/debris. CT without contrast without acute intracranial abnormality Patient subsequently developed projectile feculent vomiting and was intubated for airway protection. Following this, he developed hypotension requiring norepinephrine and a fever to 104.0. Patient received 3L NS (per report, though only recorded as 1L NS on dashboard), cefepime/flagyl, acetaminophen, and propofol > midazolam/fentanyl. He was then admitted to the MICU for further evaluation. Brief Hospital Course: with PMHx notable for schizophrenia and alzheimer's dementia and stroke (R AICA (likely artery-to-artery embolic from occluded R vertebral artery) and small vessels supratentorial infarcts (likely due to microvascular risk factors)), who was initially admitted to the MICU on from 's locked memory unit with one week of worsening lower extremity weakness, gait instability, and progressive somnolence found to have septic shock and possible GTC seizure for which he was intubated. He was treated with antibiotics for proctocolitis and pneumonia, extubated, and transferred to the medical floor with gradual improvement his mental status (to recent baseline of word responses), thought to be due likely to toxic metabolic encephalopathy the setting of poor substrate and infection. Workup during this hospitalization was also concerning for late-latent syphillis versus neurosyphilis on the basis of negative RPR with positive treponemal testing and no clear history of syphilis treatment with treatment as described below. MICU COURSE # Encephalopathy Developed acute encephalopathy ED after a week of progressive weakness and gradual encephalopathy along with lower extremity weakness. Patient underwent an extensive workup while the ICU, including an LP (attempted at bedside on night of by ICU team and then obtained successfully by neurology consult service later the day) with CSF showing 0 TNCs, protein of 32 and normal glucose, Whipple PCR, BMP, EEG etc. Concern for seizure activity and prolonged post-ictal state though EEG without overt seizure activity. Infectious evaluation did not reveal a CNS infection. Rare generalized discharges on EEG so neurology recommended continuing Keppra. Likely toxic metabolic given significant improvement mental status after antibiotic treatment. Extubated on without issue. # Feculent vomiting # CT Findings of colitis and proctitis. noted to have feculent emesis prior to presentation, intubated for airway protection, with OG tube placed on low-intermittent suction initially. CT A/P with IV contrast with no show signs of SBO or other obstructive process. Repeat CT with oral and IV contrast with no e/o obstruction or intrabdominal abscess but with evolution from proctitis to mild segmental colitis of the descending colon. Per report, patient was afebrile until after intubation, and it's unclear if he had infectious symptoms prior to presentation. Differential would include viral or bacterial gastroenteritis (given CT findings with proctitis) vs. gallstone ileus (given cholelithiasis on imaging, though patient reportedly stooling the ED) versus inflammatory bowel disease. Norovirus and C. diff negative. Continued vancomycin/cefepime/flagyl for 7d course while the ICU. Started on a clear diet after extubation on . # Undifferentiated shock and hypotension # Fever. Presented with hypotension and fever. Differential includes etiologies of distributive shock sepsis (febrile) or vasoplegia (sedation, neurologic). Sources of infection would include GI and possible CNS as above though low suspicion for bacterial meningitis as above. have had some component of hypovolemia given elevated lactate though hypotension persisted after IVF reuscitation and lactate normalization, arguing against this. Low suspicion for other causes of shock including hemorrhagic and obstructive. S/p LP as above without evidence of CNS abnormality. CT chest on showed RUL and bilateral lower lobe aspiration and likely pneumonia. CT abd/pelvis showed extension of protocolitis to include more of the colon. Was initially on vanc/cefepime flagyl and transition to cefepime and flagyl for intended 7 day course. # Hypervolemia Patient was significantly positive for LOS the setting of volume resuscitation the MICU. Grossly edematous on exam. Diuresed with IV lasix while MICU. # Central line associated thrombus Report of RUE swelling by nursing on . RUE Doppler showed non-occlusive thrombus surrounding right internal jugular venous catheter with good flow on Doppler. Placed on heparin gtt. Will need 3 months of anticoagulation. # Bradycardia. Noted to be bradycardic to the for most of ICU stay without drop BPs. Hemodynamically stable. Unclear etiology. Patient not on any culprit medications. # Transaminitis Likely medication effect. Does have cholelithiasis but bili is not elevated. RUQUS wnl, hepatitis serologies pending. Concern for DILI. Hepatitis serologies showed immunity to HBV and HAV Ab positivity, thought to represent previous infections. # Lower extremity weakness Reports of a week or so of progressive weakness. LP and exam inconsistent with GBS. Unclear etiology. # Thrombocytopenia Does not fit timeline of HITT; no recent heparin exposure prior to admission. 4 T score , low probability for HITT. Likely marrow suppression the setting of sepsis. No known liver disease. Possibly the setting of sepsis as he was noted to improve throughout the course of his ICU stay. # Anemia Hgb downtrending 12.0 > 10.5 the ED post IVF (varying reports of how much IVF given ED). Hgbs have been relatively stable since. MEDICINE FLOOR COURSE ACUTE ISSUES # Toxic metabolic encephalopathy # Seizure # Lower extremity weakness Patient initially presented with one week of worsening mental status, gait instability, and decreased verbal output. He was noted to have episodes of abnormal movements of bilateral upper and lower extremities, initially thought to be GTCs. Likely toxic metabolic encephalopathy the setting of poor substrate and sepsis. Neurology was consulted, and on further EEG review it was thought that his seizure was likely metabolic the setting of infection and his keppra was discontinued. He did have continued rigidity and tremors which were thought to be secondary to his long term antipsychotic use. However given his history of decompensation off of these medications, they were continued as he has been stabilized on this regimen thus far. # Possible Neurosyphilis vs Latent syphillis FTA-Abs reactive with negative RPR and VDRL of CSF negative. Difficult to assess for symptoms of neurosyphilis given baseline mental status and neurological exam. Patient was started on IV penicillin pending additional Treponemal Particle Agglutination testing, which also returned positive. ID was consulted, with plan to treat with a 10 day course of IV penicillin to cover for both neurosyphilis or late latent syphilis (D1: . He does not need additional treatment or testing once this course of IV PCN is completed. # HTN Persistently elevated SBPs during hospitalization, improved with increased Lisinopril to 10MG daily. # RIJ associated thrombus: RUE Doppler revealing non-occlusive thrombus surrounding RIJ venous catheter with good flow on Doppler. Placed on apixaban with plan for at least 3 month course (to . # Anemia Patient initially presented with Hgb of 12 (baseline which downtrended to a nadir of , likely acute on chronic the setting of infection/sepsis. Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable. Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or wheelchair. Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. . It was a pleasure taking care of you. Why you were admitted? You were admitted because you were found to be more confused and had an infection of your gut (colitis) and your lungs (pneumonia). What did we do for you? You were given IV antibiotics for your infections and your breathing improved. You had imaging showing no signs of stroke or bleeding your brain. You were found to have testing indicating either a previously treated case of syphilis or a late untreated case of it. You were given a course of IV penicillin for this. What should you do when you leave the hospital? We hope your strength and mobility will improve at rehab. Please take all your medications as prescribed. Please attend your followup appointments. We wish you the best, Your team. Followup Instructions:
